title: Cache poisoning Denial of Service affecting assets.gitlab-static.net

profile.name: GitLab
profile.about: A single application for the entire software development lifecycle.

vulnerability_information:
# Summary

Hi,

Gitlab.com is hosting JS and CSS on `https://assets.gitlab-static.net/` and uses them on gitlab.com/*
The static files seem to be stored on a gcp host, which by default accepts the `x-http-method-override` header. Since the CDN is using Varnish to cache files, I was able to combine the GCP behaviour and poison the cache into returning an empty resource, inherenetly causing a denial of service on gitlab.com and all gitlab assets that use the specific cdn. 

###  Disclaimer

No actual denial of service attack was caused troughout my testing. All the testing used cache-busters, meaning it did not affect the live website in any way.
 
# Steps to reproduce

1. Sending a request such as:

```http
GET /assets/webpack/commons-pages.admin.sessions-pages.groups.omniauth_callbacks-pages.ldap.omniauth_callbacks-pages.omn-c3aaf8c4.3f9d44ba.chunk.js HTTP/1.1
Host: assets.gitlab-static.net
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:87.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/87.0
Connection: close
```
will return the expected js file. 
By taking a quick look at the response headers, we can see the file is currently cached by varnish because of the following headers:
```http
Age: 498
X-Served-By: cache-dca17752-DCA, cache-osl6520-OSL
X-Cache: HIT, HIT
X-Cache-Hits: 1, 1
```
2. In order to test cache poisoning without affecting the live website, we can add random query parameters that will act as cache busters. In order to poison a resource, an attacker would send the following request:

```http
GET /assets/webpack/commons-pages.admin.sessions-pages.groups.omniauth_callbacks-pages.ldap.omniauth_callbacks-pages.omn-c3aaf8c4.3f9d44ba.chunk.js?cb=youstin-xyz HTTP/1.1
Host: assets.gitlab-static.net
x-http-method-override: HEAD
```

This will return an empty response, as it is expected from a `HEAD` request. However since the `x-http-method-override` header is not included in the cache key and the varnish configuration used does not proccess the `x-http-method-override`, this empty response will also be forwarded to all other users requesting the file, with normal GET requests. 

{F1260892}

You can also confirm the cache can be poisoned by visiting the file in your browser, making sure to include the parameter used as a cachebuster. You should notice the empty repsonse, typical to a HEAD request.

This vulnerability can be used on files used by the live site even if they are already cached, by making use of the PURGE http method, which clears the cache, allowing for an easily reproducible DoS attack.

## Impact

Since Gitlab does not forbid unauthorized users from using the PURGE http method, which clears the cache, it is possible for an attacker to clear the cache for actual JS or CSS files used on gitlab.com and poison it with an empty response. Doing so will lead to missing JS and CSS files, making gitlab completely unuseable. 
This vulnerability affects all instances of gitlab where the cdn is used for JS and CSS files.

activities.message:
Hello @youstin,

I hope all is well and thanks for leaving a message. 

Can you please submit a video of your reproducing the issue? The reason why I ask is I am never shown the poisoned version of the cache. Watching a video might help me understand how to perform the PoC to reproduce it.

Thanks and regards,
@golden__retriever

Hi @golden__retriever 

I attached a video PoC. Let me know if you have any further issues reproducing.

█████████

Hello @youstin,

I hope all is well and thanks for leaving a message. 

I am not sure what your video demonstrate can be considered cache poisoning. You might be able to cache that specific response, but the application will never request this resource, I am not sure this will be exploitable. Can you demonstrate the application actually ceasing to operate? You just show one static resource, and to be honest, when you removed the junk from the request, it seemed to function fine. I noticed this behavior you showed in the video myself when I was trying to reproduce this report.

Thanks and regards,
@golden__retriever

Hi @golden_retriever,

The video PoC I attached does demonstrate cache poisoning. 
> You just show one static resource, and to be honest, when you removed the junk from the request, it seemed to function fine. 

When creating proof of concepts for cache poisoning, cache-busters are used. The "junk from the request" are GET parameters used as the cache-buster. 
> Can you demonstrate the application actually ceasing to operate? 

The sole purpose of using a cache buster is to not actually take  down the resource since that would affect Gitlab Customers. In the same manner we can take down a resource with `?random=golden_retriever`, we can take down the actual js file. I assume you tried replicating it on the actual js file the first time and failed. That is because the resource is currently cached so even when using the `x-http-method-override` header, you are getting the cacehd response. If an attacker were to try take down the actual file, the PURGE method would help him do so. Sending the `PURGE` http method clears the cache and would make it reproducible on the actual file too. 

> Can you demonstrate the application actually ceasing to operate? 

Yes, I can demonstrate the application actually ceasing to operate. I don't think the Gitlab team & customers would appreciate it though. If the attack can be confirmed using cache-busters responsibly, I fail to understand why causing an actual DoS is needed. 

Here is some external references on Cache poisoning being demonstrated using cachebusters: 
>  The 'dontpoisoneveryone' parameter is crucial to proving that the attack is possible without actually causing site downtime. For a in-depth explanation of this technique, please refer to Practical Web Cache Poisoning.

Taken from:
https://portswigger.net/research/responsible-denial-of-service-with-web-cache-poisoning

Practical Web Cache Poisoning - https://portswigger.net/research/practical-web-cache-poisoning

I'd also like to mention that this also affects about.gitlab.com. Since the website is hosted on GCP itself, there is no need to take down js files, you can just take down `/`. While the specific subdomain is out of scope, Gitlab should also fix this one.

Hello @youstin,

Thank you for submitting this report.

We have verified this finding and have escalated to our engineering team.  We will be tracking progress internally at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/infrastructure/-/issues/13156.  This issue will be made public 30 days following the release of a patch.

Given the severity of the report, we are paying an initial $1000 on triage. Congratulations!

We will continue to update you via HackerOne as a patch is scheduled for release.

Best regards,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team

ETA for fix:

Hi @youstin,

The issue you reported is currently scheduled to be fixed by 2021-07-31.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Hi @youstin,

Thank you again for the report! Your finding has been reviewed and we are awarding a bounty prior the release of a patch. Congratulations!

We will continue to keep you updated via HackerOne as a fix is scheduled.

Best regards,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team

Just leaving a note here to mention that the impact to gitlab.com fixed on June 10th but this remains open because it's still possible to exploit it on about.gitlab.com and that's why the issue is still opened.

ETA for fix:

Hi @youstin,

The issue you reported is currently scheduled to be fixed by 2021-10-31.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Hi @youstin,

Thank you again for the report and for your patience! Your finding has been patched, congratulations!

GitLab.com doesn't use `assets.gitlab-static.net` anymore to serve assets and `about.gitlab.com` is fixed. You'll notice that `assets.gitlab-static.net` is still up and proxies to GitLab.com (see https://assets.gitlab-static.net/dcouture for example) but it isn't in use anywhere anymore which solves the security impact. We're also likely to remove the DNS record in the future.

We look forward to your next report!

Best regards,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team

summaries.content:
For more details about the vulnerability, check out:
https://youst.in/posts/cache-poisoning-at-scale/
